010package imagingbook.common.geometry.mappings.linear;
011
012import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
013import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d.PntDouble;
014import imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.points.AffineFit2d;
015import imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic;
016import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
017
018/**
019 * <p>
020 * This class represents an affine transformation in 2D, which can be defined by
021 * three pairs of corresponding points. It can be assumed that every instance of
022 * this class is indeed an affine mapping. Instances are immutable. See Secs.
023 * 21.1.3 and 21.3.1 of [1] for details.
024 * </p>
025 * <p>
026 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
027 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
028 * </p>
029 * 
030 * @author WB
031 */
032public class AffineMapping2D extends ProjectiveMapping2D {
033
034        /**
035         * Creates an affine 2D mapping from two sequences of corresponding points.
036         * If 3 point pairs are specified, the mapping is exact, otherwise a
037         * minimum least-squares fit is calculated.
038         * @param P the source points
039         * @param Q the target points
040         * @return a new {@link AffineMapping2D} instance for the two point sets
041         */
042        public static AffineMapping2D fromPoints(Pnt2d[] P, Pnt2d[] Q) {
043                if (P.length != Q.length) {
044                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("point sets P, Q must have the same size");
045                }
046                if (P.length < 3) {
047                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("at least 3 point pairs are required");
048                }
049                if (P.length == 3) {
050                        // exact fit
051                        return fromPoints(P[0], P[1], P[2], Q[0], Q[1], Q[2]);
052                }
053                else {
054                        // minimum least-squares fit
055                        AffineFit2d fit = new AffineFit2d(P, Q);
056                        return new AffineMapping2D(fit.getTransformationMatrix());
057                }
058        }
059        
060        /**
061         * <p>
062         * Creates an affine mapping from 3 pairs of corresponding 2D points
063         * (p0, p1, p2) &rarr; (q0, q1, q2).
064         * The solution is found in closed form (see [1], Sec. 21.1.3, eq. 21.31).
065         * </p>
066         * <p>
067         * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
068         * </p>
069         * 
070         * @param p0 point 1 of source triangle A
071         * @param p1 point 2 of source triangle A
072         * @param p2 point 3 of source triangle A
073         * @param q0 point 1 of source triangle B
074         * @param q1 point 2 of source triangle B
075         * @param q2 point 3 of source triangle B
076         * @return a new {@link AffineMapping2D} instance
077         */
078        public static AffineMapping2D fromPoints(Pnt2d p0, Pnt2d p1, Pnt2d p2, Pnt2d q0, Pnt2d q1, Pnt2d q2) {
079                final double px0 = p0.getX(), px1 = p1.getX(), px2 = p2.getX();
080                final double py0 = p0.getY(), py1 = p1.getY(), py2 = p2.getY();
081                final double qx0 = q0.getX(), qx1 = q1.getX(), qx2 = q2.getX();
082                final double qy0 = q0.getY(), qy1 = q1.getY(), qy2 = q2.getY();
083
084                final double d = px0 * (py2 - py1) + px1 * (py0 - py2) + px2 * (py1 - py0); 
085                if (Arithmetic.isZero(d)) {
086                        throw new ArithmeticException("affine mapping is undefined (d=0)");
087                }
088                double a00 = (py0 * (qx1 - qx2) + py1 * (qx2 - qx0) + py2 * (qx0 - qx1)) / d;
089                double a01 = (px0 * (qx2 - qx1) + px1 * (qx0 - qx2) + px2 * (qx1 - qx0)) / d;
090                double a10 = (py0 * (qy1 - qy2) + py1 * (qy2 - qy0) + py2 * (qy0 - qy1)) / d;
091                double a11 = (px0 * (qy2 - qy1) + px1 * (qy0 - qy2) + px2 * (qy1 - qy0)) / d;
092                
093                double a02 = (px0*(py2*qx1-py1*qx2) + px1*(py0*qx2-py2*qx0) + px2*(py1*qx0-py0*qx1)) / d;
094                double a12 = (px0*(py2*qy1-py1*qy2) + px1*(py0*qy2-py2*qy0) + px2*(py1*qy0-py0*qy1)) / d;
095                
096                return new AffineMapping2D(a00, a01, a02, a10, a11, a12);
097        }
098        
099//      /**
100//       * Creates an affine mapping from an arbitrary 2D triangle A to another triangle B.
101//       * @param A the first triangle
102//       * @param B the second triangle
103//       * @return a new affine mapping
104//       * @deprecated
105//       */
106//      public static AffineMapping2D from3Points(Point[] A, Point[] B) {
107//              return AffineMapping2D.from3Points(A[0], A[1], A[2], B[0], B[1], B[2]);
108//      }
109        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
110        
111        /**
112         * Creates the identity mapping.
113         */
114        public AffineMapping2D() {
115                super();
116        }
117        
118        /**
119         * Creates a linear mapping from a transformation matrix A,
120         * which must be at least of size 2 x 3.
121         * The elements of A are copied into a 3x3 identity matrix.
122         * If A is larger than 2 x 3, the remaining elements are ignored.
123         * @param A a 2x3 (or larger) matrix
124         */
125        public AffineMapping2D(double[][] A) {
126                //super(A[0][0], A[0][1], A[0][2], A[1][0], A[1][1], A[1][2], 0, 0);
127                super(extractAffineMatrix(A));
128        }
129        
130        private static double[][] extractAffineMatrix(double[][] A) {
131                double[][] M = Matrix.idMatrix(3);
132                final int m = Math.min(2, A.length);    // max. 2 rows
133                for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
134                        final int n = Math.min(3, A[i].length); // max. 3 columns
135                        for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) {
136                                M[i][j] = A[i][j];
137                        }
138                }
139                return M;
140        }
141
142        /**
143         * Creates an affine mapping from the specified matrix elements.
144         * @param a00 matrix element A_00
145         * @param a01 matrix element A_01
146         * @param a02 matrix element A_02
147         * @param a10 matrix element A_10
148         * @param a11 matrix element A_11
149         * @param a12 matrix element A_12
150         */
151        public AffineMapping2D (
152                        double a00, double a01, double a02, 
153                        double a10, double a11, double a12) {
154                super(a00, a01, a02, a10, a11, a12, 0, 0);
155        }
156
157        /**
158         * Creates a new affine mapping from an existing affine mapping.
159         * @param m an affine mapping
160         */
161        public AffineMapping2D(AffineMapping2D m) {
162                this(m.a00, m.a01, m.a02, m.a10, m.a11, m.a11);
163        }
164        
165        // ----------------------------------------------------------
166        
167        /** Deviation limit for checking 0 and 1 values. */
168        protected static double AffineTolerance = 1e-15;
169        
170        /**
171         * Checks if the given linear mapping could be affine, i.e. if the
172         * bottom row of its transformation matrix is (0, 0, 1). 
173         * Note that this is a necessary but not sufficient requirement.
174         * The threshold {@link AffineTolerance} is used in this check.
175         * @param map a linear mapping
176         * @return true if the mapping could be affine
177         */
178        public static boolean isAffine(LinearMapping2D map) {
179                if (Math.abs(map.a20) > AffineTolerance) return false;
180                if (Math.abs(map.a21) > AffineTolerance) return false;
181                if (Math.abs(map.a22 - 1.0) > AffineTolerance) return false;
182                return true;
183        }
184
185        /**
186         * Concatenates this mapping A with another affine mapping B and returns
187         * a new mapping C, such that C(x) = B(A(x)).
188         * @param B the second mapping
189         * @return the concatenated affine mapping
190         */
191        public AffineMapping2D concat(AffineMapping2D B) {      // use some super method instead?
192                double[][] C = Matrix.multiply(B.getTransformationMatrix(), this.getTransformationMatrix());
193                return new AffineMapping2D(C[0][0], C[0][1], C[0][2], C[1][0], C[1][1], C[1][2]);
194        }
195        
196        @Override       // more efficient than generic version
197        public Pnt2d applyTo(Pnt2d pnt) {
198                final double x = pnt.getX();
199                final double y = pnt.getY();
200                double x1 = (a00 * x + a01 * y + a02);
201                double y1 = (a10 * x + a11 * y + a12);
202                return PntDouble.from(x1, y1);
203        }
204
205        /**
206         * {@inheritDoc}
207         * Note that inverting an affine transformation always yields
208         * another affine transformation.
209         */
210        @Override
211        public AffineMapping2D getInverse() {
212                double det = a00 * a11 - a01 * a10;
213                double b00 = a11 / det;
214                double b01 = -a01 / det;
215                double b02 = (a01 * a12 - a02 * a11) / det;
216                double b10 = -a10 / det;
217                double b11 = a00 / det;
218                double b12 = (a02 * a10 - a00 * a12) / det;
219                return new AffineMapping2D(b00, b01, b02, b10, b11, b12);
220        }
221
222        /**
223         * {@inheritDoc}
224         * @return a new affine mapping
225         */
226        @Override
227        public AffineMapping2D duplicate() {
228                return new AffineMapping2D(this);
229        }
230
231        @Override
232        public double[][] getJacobian(Pnt2d xy) {
233                final double x = xy.getX();
234                final double y = xy.getY();
235                return new double[][]
236                        {{x, y, 0, 0, 1, 0},
237                         {0, 0, x, y, 0, 1}};
238        }
239        
240        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
241

252//              System.out.println("a = \n" + Matrix.toString(A));
253//              System.out.println();

255//              System.out.println("ai = \n" + Matrix.toString(ai));
256//              
257//              LinearMapping2D Ai = new LinearMapping2D(ai);

259//              
260//              double[][] I = Matrix.multiply(A, ai);
261//              System.out.println("\ntest: should be the  identity matrix: = \n" + Matrix.toString(I));
262//              
263//              double[][] B = 
264//                      {{-2, 4, -3}, 
265//                      {3, 7, 2}};

267//              LinearMapping2D am = new AffineMapping2D(B);
268//              System.out.println("an = \n" + Matrix.toString(am.getTransformationMatrix()));
269//      }
270
271}
